text:
Civilian writing about military matters labours under obvious difficulties, and it is necessary to offer an explanation for undertaking a task for which neither my training nor my profession qualifies me. Nearly ten years ago I began a study of the civil institutions of the Marathas with a view to exploring the causes of the expansion of their empire and its speedy and complete collapse. Every phase of the Maratha state forms an organic unit, and even a cursory examination of its character demands an enquiry into the nature of its component parts. This is the only excuse I can offer for trespassing into domains other than my own; but I am fully conscious of my limitations and I have carefully avoided all technical matters as far as possible and confined myself to those broad questions to which even a layman can do some justice. The need for such a survey was pointed out by Sydney Owen more than fifty years ago.

If the civilian student of military history suffers from some disadvantage due to his lack of technical knowledge, he is further handicapped when he selects the military history of the Marathas as the subject of his enquiry. In England, a large number of useful works on the art and science of war was written and published in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, but the Maratha commanders and strategists have left us nothing of that kind. Their military theories must, therefore, remain a subject of conjecture. Luckily facts and figures, on which such conjectures can safely be based, are not wanting, though they are still buried in unpublished records scattered in different parts of India and Europe. All the information we need cannot be found in Marathi records, but these can be profitably supplemented by contemporary English, Portuguese, French and Dutch records; and for the last phase of the Maratha military organisation we have the valuable accounts left by European military experts like Tone and Smith, who wrote from personal knowledge. On the naval history of the Marathas their own records do not throw much light, and we have to rely almost entirely on foreign sources. It has been my endeavour to piece together these widely scattered scraps of information in the following pages; with what success, it is for my readers to judge.

I have examined, as far as possible, all the manuscript records available in London, Paris, Lisbon, Evora and Goa, and I have not neglected the rare old publications likely to throw light on my subject. But these old records and manuscripts are without any index and in some cases are not in a good state of preservation. It is, therefore, possible that some papers bearing on the subject may have escaped my scrutiny.

The political history of the Marathas is now fairly well known, thanks to the monumental work of Grant Duff. It has been, therefore, possible to avoid a detailed narrative of their campaigns, but, as the average reader is yet unfamiliar with their naval activities, I have deemed it necessary to deal with that subject in greater detail; though a fuller account of the exploits of Kanhoji Angria and his sons has to be postponed for a future occasion from consideration of space. It is necessary to add a few words here about my references to Factory Records and Bombay Public Consultations. The date indicated either in the text or in the footnotes will supply a surer means of locating the extracts than the page or folio number, as each copyist seems to have numbered his own pages according to his own convenience. To avoid confusion, I have sometimes given the number of the particular part of the volume as well, but it should be noted that in the original volumes the different parts have not been separately numbered. It is also necessary to point out that in the following pages the word Maratha has not been (except when otherwise indicated) used in the caste sense.

My thanks are due to Mr. Otwell, Superintendent of Records, India Office, for permitting me to read the Bombay Public Consultations of 1700 to 1756. I take this opportunity for offering my grateful thanks for similar courtesy to Dr. Jaime de Cortesao of Biblioteca Nacional of Lisbon, Senor Pedro de Azevedo of Archivo Ultramarino of Lisbon, Dr. Lopes da Sylva of Bibliotheca Publica of Evora and M. Paul Roussier of the Colonial Office of Paris. Col. C. E. Luard has placed me under great obligations by lending me several rare publications on Maratha history and I am also indebted to Sir William Foster and Prof. Alfred Martineau for their expert guidance in my search of English and French records. Prof. Nripendra Chandra Banerji and Dr. Hem Chandra Chaudhuri have very kindly gone through my manuscripts and my friend and colleague Sri Sailendra Nath Mitra has read the proofs with his usual kindness and patience. The late Mr. S. M. Edwardes very kindly revised some of the earlier chapters and I am indebted to him for some valuable suggestions. They are not, however, in any way responsible for any shortcoming that may still disfigure this work. The bibliography indicates the fact, and not the extent, of my indebtedness. It has not been possible to print Portuguese words correctly for want of proper types, but it is hoped that this unavoidable defect will cause my readers no serious inconvenience.

This monograph was written in 1926. I long hesitated to publish it, for it was submitted as a thesis and disapproved by the examiners, Sir Verney Lovett and Mr. N. C. Seddon, both retired I.C.S. men. I then sought the advice of the late Professor Dodwell and the book was sent to press under his advice. On publication it met with the approval of many front-rank scholars and reviewers. Being the first attempt to examine the military and naval institutions of the Marathas it was prescribed as a text book by many Indian Universities and soon went out of print. I could not arrange to bring out a revised edition as I was busily engaged elsewhere. Before I left for the United States to teach at the University of Wisconsin I rapidly went through the book and made slight corrections. Mr. Adam of Orient Longmans kindly agreed to publish it; otherwise this edition might not have seen the light for a few years more. During my absence from India my old friend, Dr. A. C. Banerjee, saw the book through the press. Since the publication of the first edition I have not come across any other work on this subject. Nearly half a century ago the late Rao Bahadur Parasnis brought out a small monograph on the Maratha navy, but he depended mainly on published Marathi records although English and Portuguese records throw more light on the subject. Unfortunately I had to depend on my previous scrutiny of these papers made more than thirty years ago.

The Marathas were the last indigenous empire builders of India. They leapt into prominence suddenly and swiftly; in the third decade of the seventeenth century the Maratha name was unknown to the world outside; three decades later it had become a terror to the rulers of the land. In the second decade of the next century the Emperor of Delhi had to recognise their de facto supremacy in the Deccan by granting them chauth and sardeshmukhi of six provinces of the South. But their activities were not confined to the immediate neighbourhood of their home. Balaji Vishwanath entered Delhi in the train of Syed Husain Ali, his son appeared in its environs at the head of his victorious army, his grandsons became arbiters of the fate of the Mughal empire and carried the Maratha banner to the banks of the Indus, while their cavalry scoured the country from Lahore to Murshidabad, from Delhi to Seringapatam. The expansion of their empire was once arrested by the defeat of Panipat, but the Marathas quickly recovered from the shock; and Mahadaji Sindhia founded a new empire in Hindustan. In 1794 they inflicted a crushing defeat on the Nizam at Kharda and compelled him to cede half his territories. Hardly eight years elapsed before the Peshwa became a feudatory of the British Government in India, the armies of Daulat Rao Sindhia and Raghuji Bhonsla were defeated and destroyed by Lake and Wellesley, and the Maratha empire collapsed like a house of cards. If their rise was sudden and swift, the fall of the Marathas was no less sudden and spectacular. The Empire was apparently at the zenith of its power, it had reached its greatest extent, its man-power was almost unlimited, yet it was destroyed by a foreign power with a small army after a brief campaign of fifteen weeks. What led to this rapid and complete collapse? The plea of accidents cannot be seriously considered. In History accident plays no prominent part, and seldom turns the tide of national fortunes.

meta.theme: Rise and Fall of the Maratha Empire

text: It is true that Mahadaji Sindhia died while still in the prime of life, and about the same date died a lesser person, Hari Pant Phadke. It is true that the early death of the first Madhav Rao, the murder of Narayan Rao, the unfortunate suicide of the second Madhav Rao were national calamities of no mean order and certainly accelerated the pace of the Maratha fall. It is also true that after Nana Fadnavis there was no one competent to unite the divergent forces that constituted the complex organisation called the Maratha empire. But why did the Maratha race suddenly grow barren of great men? If the Marathas could survive Shivaji's death, why could they not survive Nana Fadnavis? If able leaders came forth to save the nation in 1690, why were they lacking in 1802? The death of Cavour did not arrest the progress of Italian unity, why should the death of Nana Fadnavis or Mahadaji Sindhia cause the downfall of the Maratha empire? Accidents offer no satisfactory explanation. Social reformers have attributed the misfortunes of the Marathas to their caste dissensions. Yet the Maratha empire came into being under the shadow of the caste system, it expanded and flourished while that system was in full operation. Shivaji, a Maratha, recruited his highest officers from the Brahman caste; the two greatest generals employed by the Brahman Peshwa in Northern India were both Marathas; Yamaji Shivdev, a Brahman, once intrigued against the Brahman Peshwa; the pretender Sadoba found an ardent supporter in Trimbak Rao Pethe, a Maratha. Caste played its part in Maratha history, but it was not the decisive factor.

meta.theme: Rise and Fall of the Maratha Empire

text: The caste system has been blamed for many of India's ills, but the true cause of the Maratha downfall lies elsewhere.  Some argue their decline stemmed from neglecting unity, their civil government's flaws, a focus on plunder over trade, industry, agriculture, and commerce.  While their civil institutions had weaknesses, they were no worse than those in contemporary Europe.  Their government did decline in the late eighteenth century, but this was a consequence, not the cause, of the decline already underway.  Nor was their fall due to their aggressive policy.  An imperial power in a region like India must be aggressive until its dominance is established.  Their diplomacy, sometimes criticized, was not unusual for the time.  In the eighteenth century, both in the East and West, abstract morality played little role in diplomacy.  Figures like Clive, Cavour, Bismarck, and Napoleon III wouldn't hesitate to deceive rivals or enemies.  If the Marathas desired their neighbors' lands, their neighbors reciprocated. The Bombay Government even instructed its envoy to Poona to exploit Maratha disunity. Vansitart considered a full-scale invasion of the Maratha empire after the Panipat disaster, despite existing peace.  Had Panipat's outcome differed, Vansitart's protégé in Murshidabad would have faced Maratha might.  However, an aggressive policy requires effective tools. An imperial power needs a strong military.  The Maratha empire thrived as long as its army remained effective; its decline began when the army weakened, making way for a better-equipped rival. Examining the Maratha army's decline may reveal the true causes of the empire's downfall.  The army reflects the state. The Maratha state began as an enlightened autocracy with a national monarchy and a national army.  This evolved into a feudal despotism, and the army became a feudal force, lacking discipline and homogeneity.  Under the Peshwas, there wasn't a unified army but a collection of forces led by feudal chiefs with differing ideals and interests. This hampered the state's military potential and prevented unified command.  Further, the state abandoned its original ideal, and foreign mercenaries replaced national elements within the army. This alone doesn't explain their defeat, as the English army also used mercenaries.  Even disunited, some Maratha chiefs fielded larger forces than the English.  Their defeat stems from inferior discipline, equipment, and command. Early Maratha success stemmed from superior discipline compared to their Muslim rivals.  As their empire grew and wealth flowed in, they adopted the Mughal military's luxurious habits, which weakened discipline. The later Peshwa's army suffered from the same issues that brought down their Muslim predecessors.  Maratha weaponry was diverse, reflecting various stages of civilization, some dating back to the Stone Age.  Bows and arrows were used alongside matchlocks and muskets, even stones were employed as projectiles.  Their tactics were similarly mixed.  They adopted new tactics from their European adversaries without discarding traditional methods. These proved incompatible, leading to disaster.  Maratha chiefs with their cavalry clung to old ways, while new battalions of foreign mercenaries were led by officers of questionable skill and varying nationalities. This army was no match for the English.  The command's inefficiency stemmed from the feudal organization and their inability to modernize military and civil institutions. The Maratha decline resulted from the resurgence of feudalism after Sambhaji's death, which caused disunity; the abandonment of Shivaji's ideal of racial amity for personal gain, which led to the army's denationalization; and the failure to keep up with global scientific progress, learn from others, and improve upon what they learned. Europe progressed from feudalism to monarchy and then democracy; the Peshwas reversed this in Maharashtra, leading to the Maratha empire's decline and fall.

A strong army requires more than just skilled soldiers; a nation of warriors doesn't automatically equate to a powerful military. Military effectiveness requires discipline among the troops and imaginative yet pragmatic leadership. Above all, a military power needs a motivating ideal to defend and fight for. The Marathas had a reputation as soldiers as early as the seventh century A.D., but they didn't rise to prominence among India's major powers until the second half of the seventeenth century. Until then, they were disunited, disorganized, and prone to internal conflict.  We know little about their early military organization.  They likely served under the Chalukya and Rashtrakuta banners.  Their warrior nature is evident, as Hiuen Tsang noted their martial qualities.  However, details about their arms, wartime organization, officer cadre, and tactics remain unknown.  Following the Chalukyas and Rashtrakutas came the Yadava and Silahara dynasties, both of Maratha origin. The Silaharas ruled small Konkan and Karhad principalities, while the Yadavas had a larger kingdom. Yadava inscriptions boast of their elephants and Dandanayakas (military commanders), common features in Indian armies of the time.  However, their kingdom's quick collapse against an external enemy doesn't suggest strong military capability.  Chronicles of the Turkish conquest of the Deccan don't mention the harassing tactics later Marathas used effectively against the Delhi army. Ramchandra Deva, the last independent Yadava king, became a Turkish vassal after his large army was defeated by a smaller Muslim force.  His son-in-law's failed rebellion against Muslim rule led to the Marathas' disappearance from historical records for centuries.  They don't reappear until the Bahmani kingdom's fall. During this absence, they hadn't been inactive.  They lost political independence but not their land entirely.  The terrain provided natural defenses, and their villages, though scattered, were fortified. Deshmukhs (feudal lords) could resist invaders for months in their hilltop strongholds.  Lacking a strong sense of national honor (the concept of nationality was still developing), they pragmatically accepted Muslim sovereignty in exchange for peaceful possession of their lands and rights. The Muslim conquerors recognized the limits of their power and didn't overreach. Thus, Maratha chiefs maintained control over their small, protected territories after the Yadava and Silahara princes were replaced by a stronger power.  However, peace wasn't the norm.  The climate and terrain fostered courage and endurance but also made the Marathas self-centered and parochial.  Their ambition rarely extended beyond their own villages or, for chiefs, their paternal principalities.  But for every Maratha, their watan (homeland) was paramount, akin to the Rajput's bapoti. They would sacrifice anything, even their faith, for it.

religion was not too high a to pay for its retention. As each watan had more than one claimant; it caused continual strife between rival chiefs and rival families. And as the Maratha of those did not readily forget a loss or forgive an injury, these quarrels inevitably led to blood feuds, which could only be ended by the complete extermination of one of the rival families. Such hostilities kept the Maratha so busily engaged that he had hardly time or inclination to notice the movements and progress of the external world. The habit narrowed his vision but made a soldier of him; and thus when the time came, he was ready to take advantage of the new situation and improve his fortunes. After the dissolution of the Bahmani kingdom the Maratha chiefs began to extend their view and sought civil and military situations in the new courts. They were welcomed by all the new houses who had partitioned the old kingdom. The policy of rival houses was uncertain and shifting and their alliances were not of long duration; and they had no hesitation in joining their Hindu neighbour of Vijayanagar against a brother Muhammadan Prince. After the battle of Talikota they employed their energy and resources in the conquest of the weakest members of the confederacy, Berar and Bidar. Yet when this was accomplished the survivors found themselves unable to compose their differences, and while in this position, were suddenly confronted by a new menace from the North. These continual wars offered excellent opportunities to Maratha soldiers and Maratha diplomats, who were as eager to earn new as to retain their old watans. The beginning of the seventeenth century saw many Marathas in high positions in the military and the civil services of the Ahmadnagar, Bijapur and Golkonda Governments.

In 1618 Malik Ambar employed a Brahman diplomat, Kasi Pandit, to negotiate peace between Ahmadnagar and the Portuguese state in India. Four copies of the treaty resulting from this negotiation were made – two in Portuguese and two in the 'Hindu language,' or, more accurately, 'Hindu alphabet.' This clearly testifies to the growing influence of the Hindus in the court of their Muslim rulers. A fresh treaty was concluded two years later and as before two copies of the treaty, apparently for the use of the Indian signatory, were prepared in the Hindu language instead of Persian. In this interesting document the date of the Hindu calendar is given side by side with those of the Persian and Portuguese reckoning. It was, however, in the army that the Marathas particularly distinguished themselves. The art of war was still in its primitive infancy; weapons like sword and spear, bow and arrows, lance and dagger, which demanded little or no technical knowledge were still in general use, so that every able-bodied man was a potential soldier. He could enlist as a 'Bargir' or, if he had means enough to buy a horse and the slender outfit that a soldier needed in those days, he could join as a 'Silhedar' with much better prospects of advancement. A well-to-do Silhedar was really a condottiere leader with his own followers whose services he could utilize as he chose. Naturally he tried to secure the best market for his commodity. This was the time-honoured system in India and it is at least as old as the Sukranitisara. Neither time nor foreign conquest had affected it in the least. Success added to the Silhedar's reputation and following and of course improved his worldly prospects, for his reward generally came in the shape of a jahgir or military fief. It was in this way that some Maratha families rose to prominence.

meta.use_case: Historical analysis of Maratha military system

text: The most important of them in rank as well as in power were the Mores of Jawli with the twin titles of Raja and Chandra Rao. Next came the Savantas of Wari, the Ghorpades of Mudhol, the Nimbalkars of Phaltan, the Jadhavs of Sindkhed, the Shirkes, only lately dislodged from their paternal principality, the Surves with whom the Shirkes had found an asylum, the Mahadiks, the Mohites and the Ghatges. Of less note were chiefs like the Jedhes, the Manes and the Dafles. These families formed the military aristocracy of the land, but it should not be forgotten that in Maharashtra the profession of arms was not limited to the noble few. The social barrier was neither strong nor insuperable. The Shelars and the Jadhavas, descendants of ruling kings, had declined in the scale, the Pawars, another princely family, had reconciled themselves to their humble lot and no longer hesitated to marry Kunbi girls of lowly origin. They still affected the title of 'Raje' after their first name, but that was the only trace of royalty now left to them. This society was naturally democratic, and the common dangers, common risks, and common adventures of a soldier's life levelled what difference might have survived. A promising young man who had only recently rejected the plebeian plough for the more aristocratic sword, could aspire to the hand of a daughter of the Nimbalkars, and could demand a matrimonial alliance with the princely family of the Jadhavas. Social intercourse was more intimate and less formal than what is possible in a modern barrack, and an able leader of magnetic personality commanded not only the admiration but also the affection of his following. The common soldiers, except the few who formed the King's bodyguard, had nothing to do with the state but looked for pay, promotion and preference to the Jahgirdar under whom they immediately served. A loyal Jahgirdar contributed to the strength of the Government; but in those days it was no discredit to set up as a 'proud palegar' or lawless chief; as once did a Nimbalkar and a Jedhe. Yet the state continued its policy of multiplying the military fiefs and conferring fresh jahgirs on each enterprising Silhedar. Even a wise prince like Muhammad Adilshah laid down that while a disloyal Zemindar should be deprived of his fief, the loyal lord should on no account be discouraged or disturbed. The inevitable result of this policy was that the civil Government of the country was subordinated to military needs and the major portion of Maharashtra was held by a number of military leaders serving under three different masters. When Shivaji rose to power, the principality of Ahmadnagar had already been annexed by the Emperor of Delhi and the kingdoms of Bijapur and Golkonda were awaiting a similar fate. The question may very well be asked why did the Maratha Jahgirdars not make common cause against their Muslim masters and assert their independence? The answer is that everybody acted for himself and would not co-operate with his brother chiefs (in another kingdom) except for personal reasons. The Mughal power was deemed invincible; the weakness of the two surviving offshoots of the Bahmani kingdom was not yet apparent; they were still planning and making fresh conquests in the Karnatak. And people who have anything to lose do not generally favour change.

text:
While the Marathas claimed a common origin, a common language, and professed a common faith in normal circumstances, religious persecution alone could unite them under a common banner. The Muslim rulers of the South normally pursued a policy of religious toleration, and on occasions when a chief of note was compelled to forsake his father's faith, the pangs of conscience were forgotten in the arms of a princess. The Mughal annexation of Ahmadnagar, however, introduced a new element in southern politics, the more orthodox, the more uncompromising and the more bigoted belief of Shahjahan and Aurangzib; and the repeated invasions from which the subjects of Bijapur and Golkonda suffered and the scant consideration with which solemn treaties were treated by ambitious Viceroys like Aurangzib created an atmosphere of distrust and disquiet. Simultaneously a new spirit had been infused into Hinduism in the Deccan by what is popularly known as the Pandharpur movement. This, in short, was the situation when Shivaji appeared in the political arena.

With the advent of Shivaji a new era opened in the military history of the Marathas. He had a clear conception of military organization, definite plans of military reform and views and opinions based upon past experience. He believed in personal selection but had no faith in hereditary genius. He approved of unity of command, but would not tolerate military interference in the civil administration of the country. He wanted a strong monarchy as the only antidote to the prevailing discord, dissension and anarchy, and could not therefore reconcile himself to feudalism and all that it stood for. He had some advantage over his antagonists; his hands were not tied by precedents; but at the same time, as the founder of a new kingdom and a new house, he could not ignore the tradition of the land, nor could he afford wholly to alienate the vested interests. His first steps were naturally cautious and circumspect. He started operations with a small force attached to his father's jahgir, which probably needed few officers. But as soon as this force was augmented by the addition of Sambhaji Mohite's cavalry a Sarnobat or Commander-in-chief was appointed. With the Sarnobatship of Mankoji Dahatonde the strength of the army was 3,000 and by 1659, if we can believe Krishnaji Anant Sabhasad, Shivaji was in a position to put ten thousand cavalry and ten thousand Mawle infantry into the field. In this army the Silhedars did not preponderate although at first Shivaji had to depend mainly on these free-lances. Of the three thousand horsemen under Mankoji Dahatonde, fully two thousand were Silhedars; but by 1659 the strength of the paga or cavalry had risen to seven thousand, while the Silhedars numbered only three thousand. section: Military Organization and Doctrine of Shivaji Maharaj
text: Silhedar cavalry had declined from 66% to 33% of the total cavalry force.  Muslim historians like Khafi Khan noted Shivaji's preference for bargirs (state-provided cavalry) over silhedars (personally maintained cavalry). Bhimsel, who served under a Bundela chief, corroborates this, mentioning that while Shivaji employed silhedars, the better-paid troops were bargirs. Krishnaji Anant Sabhasad confirms the dominance of the paga (regular cavalry) over the silhedars. This emphasis on regular cavalry enhanced discipline within Shivaji's army.  Crucially, Shivaji established a clear officer cadre for both infantry and cavalry to ensure unity of command. The cavalry hierarchy started with the Havaldar (25 horsemen), then Jumledar (5 Havaldars), Hazari (10 Jumledars), Panchhazari (5 Hazaris), culminating in the Sarnobat, who reported directly to Shivaji.  A parallel civil administration supported the army, with Majumdars (accountants), Karbharis, and Jamnis attached to various levels of command.  News writers, independent of military command, reported directly to Shivaji or his Vaknavis (intelligence chief).  The infantry was organized similarly, with Naiks (10 men), Jumledars (5 Naiks), Hazaris, and a Sarnobat of infantry, although the latter held a lower status than the cavalry Sarnobat.  Civil assistants like Sabnis managed accounts and muster rolls.  Cavalry officers received significantly higher salaries than their infantry counterparts. The Jumledar of cavalry earned 500 Hons annually, the Hazari 1,000 Hons, and the Panchhazari 2,000 Hons. The Sarnobat's salary remains unspecified, but records suggest his honors were comparable to the Peshwa and even Shivaji himself.

section: Compensation and Recruitment Practices of Shivaji Maharaj
text: Unlike the prevalent Mughal and Bijapur systems of granting hereditary jagirs (land grants) for service, Shivaji favored direct payment to his officers and soldiers, partly in cash and partly in kind, which was common practice at the time.  Payments were made from the central treasury or through varats (assignments on provincial revenue).  While district officers facilitated these payments, assignees were strictly prohibited from interfering with revenue collection. Any government land held by an assignee had its rent deducted from their salary, with the balance paid in cash or varat. Shivaji actively worked to dismantle feudalism by curtailing the powers of Deshmukhs and Deshpandes (local hereditary officials) and demolishing their fortified castles.  He avoided creating new fiefs to prevent military tyranny and feudal anarchy.  No military position in his army was hereditary, and all officers were subject to dismissal, transfer, or reprimand based on their performance.  Shivaji appointed five different Sarnobats of cavalry during his reign: Tukoji, Mankoji Dahatonde, Netaji Palkar, Kadtoji Gujar, and Hasaji Mohite.  This demonstrates that appointments were based on merit, not inheritance. Similarly, Tanaji Malusare’s successor was chosen for competence, not kinship. Although rejecting hereditary jagirs, Shivaji rewarded merit through titles and honors, as seen with Kadtoji Gujar and Hasaji Mohite.

MILITARY SYSTEM OF THE MARATHAS

...circular sunshade, and a palki was granted to deserving officers. Presents of gold, silver ornaments and money were made to officers and men for acts of conspicuous bravery. Wounded men received allowances according to the nature of their injuries, and widows of soldiers killed in action were suitably pensioned. A similar pension was granted to the minor children of fallen soldiers, and these were taken into service as soon as they came of age.

The abolition of the jahgir system was not the only reform at which Shivaji aimed. He wanted to introduce strict discipline in his army. His success in this direction was far from complete, for he had to fight tradition and environment. Nonetheless, he deserves credit for his attempt. His army was employed in mulkgiri or foreign expeditions for eight months in the year. They returned to cantonment when the monsoon broke and the four months of the rainy season had to be spent in barracks in enforced idleness. Shivaji laid down that provision and medicine for men and fodder for their horses should be carefully stored in the cantonments. During the active season, the Maratha army subsisted on the spoils of war, but here it was clearly laid down that the prize belonged to the state and not to the army. Women, Brahmans, and cows were not to be molested on any account. It was a capital offence to bring a female slave or a dancing girl into the camp. It was probably military discipline and not moral reform that he strove to achieve.

Krishnaji Anant Sabhasad tells us that Shivaji inflicted exemplary punishment on some of his soldiers for breach of discipline during the Karnatak expedition. But it was impossible to effect such a moral revolution all at once. From the preamble of a Portuguese treaty, it appears that Shivaji's men had carried away men, women, children, and cattle from Portuguese territories. In 1672, some soldiers had been guilty of disorderly conduct at Chaphal. In 1676, Shivaji had to address a letter of admonition to the regiment encamped at Chiplun; from the text of the letter, it appears that they had taken away from the civil population by force what could be and should have been obtained by peaceful purchase. But when we remember how the Mughal soldiery destroyed the standing crops on their marches, drew out the straw from the thatch to feed their horses, and compelled the unoffending villagers to carry their baggage, we feel inclined to judge Maratha delinquencies more leniently. War does not bring out the best side of human nature.

But in some of his disciplinary reforms Shivaji was notably successful, and his camp was entirely free from the undesirable presence of women of easy virtue, as we are informed by two European travellers. John Fryer, the East India Company's physician, tells us that "whores and dancing wenches" were not allowed in Shivaji's camp. Navarette went to Surat and spent a few days there in 1671. “I was told at Surat,” he writes, “that Sabagi [Shivaji] the Mogal was extraordinarily careful that no woman should be in his army; and, if he happened to find one, he immediately turned her out, first cutting her hair and ears. This to prevent the effect of sensuality on the alertness and activity of his troops, for the same reason as the Tartars.” The good Bishop did not know that Shivaji was not a Mughal, but his evidence shows what reputation the Maratha leader enjoyed as a strict disciplinarian.

There is reason to believe that women were very seldom molested by Shivaji's soldiers; for a brave Mughal governor once deemed it safest to leave his women in a woman's garb at the gates of his city when the Marathas appeared. This was accomplished in an age when a Mughal general had in his camp 400 dancing girls from Kabul and Lahore to enliven his leisure. On their march, the Maratha army of Shivaji was not encumbered with much baggage or equipment. Their arms were of the simplest and most primitive kind. Field-artillery they had none; and the elaborate and comfortable camp equipage of their Mughal adversaries they did not require. The men wore a turban, a simple jacket, and tight trousers; their officers were better protected with a helmet and an armour of chain or, more frequently, with thick coats of padded cotton. In their saddlebag, they carried with ease the scanty provision on which they and their mounts could subsist for days. In his second expedition to Surat, Shivaji had no tent with him, and the Dutch spy found him sitting on the ground. In his longer and more elaborately organised Karnatak expedition, he had only two small tents, one for himself and the other for his minister, as we learn from Martin, the French Governor of Pondichery, and it is no wonder that, thus lightly equipped, the Maratha army was able to cover forty-five to fifty miles in a single march. In fact, this constituted their greatest advantage over their heavily armed and heavily armoured Muhammadan adversaries. Man for man, the Maratha horseman was no match for the Mughal or the Bijapuri, but they were not absolutely sure of victory and would not risk a pitched battle. Superior discipline, hardihood, and greater speed more than compensated for the slighter build and the lighter weight of the Maratha soldiers.

Let us now see how the contrast impressed two European contemporaries, an English Doctor of Medicine and an Italian Doctor of Law. John Fryer gives the following estimate of the merits and demerits of the rival armies:

"Seva Gi's Men thereby being fitter for any Martial Exploit, having been accustomed to Fare Hard, Journey Fast, and take little Pleasure: But the other will miss of their Booty rather than a Dinner; must mount in State and have their arms carried before them, and their Women not far behind them, with the Master of mirth and jollity; will rather expect than pursue a Foe; but then stand it out better; For Seva Gi's men care not much for a pitched Field, though they are good at Surprizing and Ransacking; yet they agree in this, that they are both of stirring Spirits."

A Francis Gemelli Careri visited India in 1695 and the Shivaji he speaks of was Ram Raja or Ram Rao as he calls him. 'This Shivaji,' he writes, 'whom his Subjects call Raja, which signifies petty King, is so Powerful, that he maintains war at once and the same time with the Great Mogul, and the Portuguese: He brings into the Field 50,000 Horse, and as many or more Foot, much better Soldiers than the Moguls, for they Live upon a piece of dry Bread, and the Moguls will March at their Ease carrying their Women, abundance of Provisions, and Tents so that their Army looks like a moving City.'

The achievements of Shivaji’s army need not detain us; they are well known. The Maratha chroniclers assert with evident pride that he fought with success against four great powers. The numerical strength of his army has been variously stated. Krishnaji Anant Sabhasad puts it well above 100,000. But the causes of his military success are not far to seek: Superior discipline, leadership and the unquestioning confidence of his men account for the brilliant victories which the great Maratha obtained over the Mughals, the Portuguese, the Bijapuris and the Haidrabadis, not to mention the petty poligars who acknowledged his suzerainty. But the main question yet remains to be answered: Why did the self-seeking, watan-loving Marathas submit to Shivaji’s leadership? Their devotion no doubt was due to the personal magnetism of the leader, but what first caught their imagination and made them forget their agelong policy of blood-feud and personal aggrandizement?

In that age, the idea of nationality was yet unborn; but race and religion still stirred the deepest sentiments of the Maratha peasant soldiery. Shivaji's ideal was a Hindvi Swarajya (Hindu empire), a Maharashtra Padshahi (Maratha dominion), but above all a Dharma Rajya, a kingdom of righteousness. He assumed the title of Go Brahman pratipalak, prioritizing the protection of cows and the priestly caste.  Brahmans fought alongside the untouchables for this cause. Shivaji's conception of a Hindu empire was not synonymous with religious persecution. His army included Pathan deserters, Muslim naval commanders, and he venerated both Hindu and Muslim saints. He granted inam lands to Muslim shrines and maintained mosques through state allowances.  He respected the Quran and protected the women and religious texts of both Hindus and Muslims during raids. This ideal resonated with the Marathas, who saw in Shivaji a deliverer of their ancestral lands.

section: Shivaji's Followers and the Legacy of his Ideal
text: The established aristocracy did not readily embrace Shivaji's call.  While some yielded to force, they remained reluctant.  Shivaji's support base consisted primarily of the masses – the farmers, laborers, and common people.  His message resonated with Hindus beyond Maharashtra, as evidenced by the poet Bhushan's journey to Raigad and the Bundela chief Chhatrasal's admiration. Shivaji was even compared to Julius Caesar and Gustavus Adolphus. This ideal, however, faded after Shivaji's death. His successors reverted to feudal practices, losing sight of the unifying vision.  The army's discipline declined, and the primary commonality between Shivaji's campaigns and those of his later successors became the collection of Chauth.

meta.use_case: Shift in Maratha Focus from Idealism to Pragmatism

text: The term 'chauth' is often linked to the Marathas, perceived as a reflection of their predatory nature. However, Shivaji did not invent this revenue system, nor was it exclusive to the Marathas. Even before Shivaji, the Rajput chief of Dharampur levied chauth from Portuguese subjects in Daman. After Shivaji conquered these territories, he inherited this right and extended the demand to Basscin.  Negotiations ensued, documented in letters that reveal chauth's pre-Maratha existence. A letter from the Portuguese Viceroy to Shivaji in 1678 acknowledges the prior payment of chauth to a 'Chauthia' and agrees to investigate the terms of the existing agreement before transferring the payments to Shivaji.  This exchange demonstrates the established practice of chauth before Maratha dominance.

meta.theme: Shivaji's justification for Chauth and Mughal vulnerability
meta.use_case: Exploiting weakness, justifying plunder as a military necessity

text:
Shivaji's military practices involved demanding chauth, a military contribution, from vulnerable subjects in enemy territories. This payment aimed to protect lives and property from his invading army. Unlike later interpretations, Shivaji didn't claim chauth as a hereditary right or based on imperial decree; it was purely based on his military strength.  If he couldn't enforce the demand, he lacked legal recourse.  He prioritized protecting the population from his soldiers' excesses, especially in annexed territories.
Chauth remained consistent under Sambhaji and Rajaram. For two decades, this payment, while called chauth, differed from its original form. It wasn't until Shahu's reign that the system reverted. Shahu received as a pension what Shivaji demanded as tribute, and provided as an obligation what Shivaji offered as a favor.  For the Mughals, chauth was a purchase of peace and security. Under Aurangzeb, demanding it defied imperial authority, but under Bahadur Shah, it signaled acceptance of the Emperor's sovereignty. The Marathas never relinquished their chauth claims in the Deccan and enforced them whenever possible. They sent messengers demanding payment from governors or zamindars, who often complied to avoid conflict.  This ensured the safety of their lands and people. They sometimes underreported their revenue to reduce the payment, but any agreed-upon sum was secured with guarantees.

section: Evolution of Chauth under Shahu and the Mughals
text: Shahu, influenced by his time in the Mughal camp, recognized the Emperor as India's legitimate ruler. He and his cousin aimed to gain Mughal support by securing an imperial farman for the chauth and sardeshmukhi of six Deccan provinces.  Delhi's ministers exploited Maratha internal conflicts, delaying the farman.  However, regional officials like Daud Khan prioritized maintaining order and protecting the peasantry, the source of state revenue.  He proposed that Mughal officers collect the chauth, preventing Maratha interference in Mughal administration. The Emperor rejected this.  Chinkulich Khan, his successor, also opposed it. Syed Hussain Ali initially tried curbing Maratha activities, but political events forced him to seek a Maratha alliance at any cost.  He negotiated a deal where Maratha officers received a share of land revenue, sair (taxes on government and jagirdar lands), and sardeshmukhi (10% levy on peasants).  This complex system, with multiple collectors, burdened the population, and though beneficial to cultivators by ensuring protection, undermined Mughal sovereignty. This led to Maratha territorial expansion by absorbing chauth-paying districts, prompting Nizam-ul-Mulk to pay them to leave his territory. He paid a fixed sum from his treasury instead of the suba of Hyderabad's chauth and abolished sardeshmukhi, freeing traders and travelers from the rahdari impost.

section: Formalization of Chauth and Shahu's Obligations
text: The concession of chauth wasn't unconditional. Balaji Vishwanath led a Maratha force to Delhi with Syed Hussain Ali, and the Viceroy's grant of chauth and sardeshmukhi was confirmed by the Emperor.  An extant farman details the terms: Shahu, as a loyal vassal, would provide 15,000 troops to the Deccan Viceroy. In return, he pledged to restore deserted and devastated areas to prosperity.

meta.use_case: Formalizing tribute, military alliance, regional development

section: Chauth and Sardeshmukhi as Pension and Tribute
text: Shahu, by accepting chauth and sardeshmukhi under the Emperor's terms, effectively became a servant of the Delhi Emperor, a position Shivaji had resisted. Chauth transformed from a predatory levy into a pension, similar to how the Portuguese viewed it in their dealings with the Raja Chauthia of Rannagar. While Shahu and his successors rarely honored their obligations, the Emperor struggled to enforce the terms of his farman, leading to mutual recriminations and inconsistent payments. Maratha chiefs often negotiated lower sums, as the financial gains from raids didn't always meet expectations. Khafi Khan noted that Maratha leaders preferred settling chauth amounts to avoid unchecked plunder by their troops, a sentiment echoed by Dutch Admiral Stavorinus, who observed that states found it more economical to pay tribute than to raise armies for defense. Stavorinus also highlighted the Maratha chiefs' self-interest in upholding agreements, as larger-scale invasions would enrich their troops at their own expense.

meta.use_case: Historical Analysis of Maratha Revenue Practices

text: The question of whether Marathas offered protection in exchange for chauth is debated. Ranade argues that Shivaji offered protection to Bijapur and Golconda against Mughal aggression in exchange for tribute, and this system was later adopted by Wellesley. However, this claim lacks supporting evidence. The treaties between Shivaji and the aforementioned Sultans are unavailable, and Shivaji continued to raid their territories.  Furthermore, the Portuguese accounts suggest negotiations for chauth collection, not sardeshmukhi, and protection was not a condition.  Shivaji's exaction of chauth from Mughal provinces was also non-consensual. This contrasts sharply with Wellesley's subsidiary alliances, which involved the surrender of diplomatic independence by allied states in exchange for protection by the East India Company, leaving internal affairs untouched. Shahu's arrangement differed significantly, as he took responsibility for maintaining order in six Deccan provinces and offered military service, without requiring the Mughal government to relinquish diplomatic independence or follow his dictates.

section: Evolution of Maratha Revenue Practices and Comparisons
text: During the Peshwaships of Balaji Baji Rao and Madhav Rao I, terms like 'khandani' and 'mamlat' encompassed Maratha claims. 'Mamlat' applied to weaker states like the Rajput principalities, who were expected to pay regularly and without resistance. It wasn't used for more powerful entities like the Nizam or Mysore, with whom the Marathas never established subsidiary alliances.  However, weaker states likely anticipated some protection, as suggested by a 1746-7 sanad where the Chief of Bhandawar ceded half his territory to the Peshwa in return for defense. This contrasts with subsidiary alliances where protection wasn't tied to chauth but to territorial concessions. An agreement with Rao Raja Umed of Bundi in 1769-70 required punctual tribute payment and forbade alliances with Maratha enemies, offering protection 'according to the agreement' without specifying its nature. Chauth wasn't exclusive to the Marathas; Raja Chumput also levied it from neighboring officials for peace and protection.  Chhatrasal, when warring against the Emperor, planned to levy chauth until the Emperor agreed to pay it in return for peace. Sikhs in cis-Sutlej regions also extracted 'rakhi' from their neighbors, initially 12.5% of revenue, increasing to 50% with their growing power. Some reports indicate Sikhs also demanding chauth.

text: It is not generally known that the English also on one occasion received chauth from two petty chiefs of the Bombay Presidency. This chauth was not obtained by military expeditions or plundering raids; instead, the Maratha rights were transferred to the English in 1802 through an agreement. Baji Rao II sought English assistance after his flight from Poona. The treaty of Bassein in 1802 practically marked the end of the Maratha imperial power. Among the territorial and other rights conceded are mentioned 'Waunsda Choute' which amounted to 7,000 Rupees, 'Durumpoory Choute' 9,000 Rupees; and 'Surat Choute' 421,000 Rupees. Surat, until recently, formed an integral part of British India, and chauth no longer constituted any part of its revenue; however, the Raja of Dharampur continued to pay chauth to his British suzerain until India attained independence. The English ensured to include the chauth in all the territorial cessions obtained from the Peshwa's Government, knowing that as long as the Marathas retained the right of collecting this contribution from the ceded districts, the English would never be secure from their interference.

text: The cession of the Dharampur chauth could not cause the English any inconvenience, while the cession of the Surat chauth was doubly welcome, as it gave them, in practice if not in theory, full and undisputed dominion over that district of South Gujarat. It is noted that the Marathas once imposed this humiliating impost to their hated enemy of Janjira, as shown by the treaty of 1755 (concluded between the Peshwa Balaji Baji Rao and the English East India Company). text: appeal yield profit. regular large appeal against Sing, My bibhag, 60 MILITARY SYSTEM or THE MARATHAS Bhagirath made 2 streams flow from the north to the south for twenty four years. Thanks to his blessings, that stream is still ever increasing and has completely satisfied the rulers of the provinces, the leaders of the army and my sincere friends. The stream has added to thirst only. Raghuji and Fatte Baba had in the past brought a stream from the south but its flow was interrupted at places. For many years in the interval the stream from the south did not flow. By God's grace the stream of wealth is flowing well in this army this year but there are many lands on the way to Poona and it will be entirely absorbed (in transit). On that account: If the northern and the southern streams could in their high flood be united at Poona without any absorption on their way, then I could get rid of my debts and secure rewards of my labour both in this world and the next. The Ganges flows to the sea but saves the whole world; in the like manner do these northern and southern rivers flow in the present age and benefit many people. All rivers and streams flow to the ocean, the Kaveri alone has been brought to the service of men. So do these rivers of wealth render but little service to the main interest, though do immense good to other people. It is proper that people with an insight should take into consideration the rights and the wrongs of this matter and so act that the sterility of Poona may be removed. The Peshwa's meaning is transparent, and the policy adumbrated in the letter was bound, when followed to its logical end, to produce one result only- namely, the wholesale alienation of his father's Hindu allies and the complete denationalisation of the Maratha army. Balaji Baji Rao like his predecessors still professed to be a champion of Hinduism: He wrote respectful letters to Brahmans of known sanctity, granted them pensions and allowances, and sometimes remitted their rent, and in his letters he often expressed an ardent desire to recover from the Muhammadans the holy places of Benares and Muttra. But Brahmans and holy men were not the only Hindus; and while they might shower their blessings on the Peshwa and his family, the Hindu princes alone could assist him in his wars against the Muhammadans. Evidently Balaji Baji Rao cared more for their money than for their armed forces, for it is during his regime that the Maratha arms fell heavily on their Rajput co-religionists.

Hitherto the Rajputs had welcomed this new power from the south as the avenger of Hindu wrongs in the north; but Balaji and his principal Sardars, Sindhia and Holkar, made the Rajput realise that Maratha supremacy meant for them nothing but a change of masters, and the change was by no means for the better. So when the Marathas stood in urgent need of men and money in 1760 and 1761 the Rajputs remained sternly aloof; while all the Muhammadan princes and nobles of Northern India, including the Nawab of Oudh whom the Marathas had done their utmost to conciliate and gratify, rallied to the Afghan banner. Nor were these the only evil effects of the selfish policy of plunder and raid. It caused disunion and dissension within the Maratha empire. The Peshwa, in want of money, did not hesitate to sell his assistance to the Nawab of Bengal against Raghuji Bhonsla of Nagpur. Raghuji, indeed, was not well-disposed towards Balaji; but the moral effect of fighting a Maratha Sardar, while employed in a Muhammadan province, was simply disastrous. Baji Rao did not seek foreign aid in his fight against the Senapati; but Balaji extended his protection to Bengal, a Sardar of the Empire; he joined the English in order to bring about the destruction of the Angria; and his son simply emulated his example when he coalesced with Nizam Ali against Janoji Bhonsle. Thus the unhappy Raghoba certainly committed no unprecedented offence when he sought military aid to secure the musnad of Poona. Balaji lamented the differences between Sindhia and Holkar and earnestly urged them to adopt a common policy in Rajputana, but he conveniently forgot that with the example he had set in Bengal the only common policy they could be expected to pursue was one of 'self-aggrandisement'. It is needless to remark that although the bulk of the Maratha army consisted of feudal levies, the Peshwa had an additional force of his own. The composition of this personal force was naturally affected by the change of political ideal and political outlook. Shivaji aimed at the foundation of a Maratha empire, and his army was mainly, if not wholly, composed of Marathas. The Pathan regiment he enlisted, probably consisted of Deccani Musulmans, who were for all practical purposes children of the soil and were by no means favourably inclined towards the Mughal empire. It is noteworthy that on one occasion Shivaji politely rejected the services of a Bundela chief. Baji Rao's proclaimed ambition was the restoration of Hindu supremacy in India and he naturally tried his best to win the moral and material support of Hindus all over the country for military purposes; but we have no documentary evidence that the non-Maratha elements formed by any means a predominating proportion of his army.

text: Balaji's sole aim was to cause the two rivers of gold from the north and the south to unite and flow into the reservoir of Poona, and this policy connoted constant fighting and a vast army. The Marathas were not very eager to spend the whole year away from their home provinces and Balaji enlisted mercenaries from all parts of India and outside India. Sikhs, Rajputs, Sindhis and Karnatakis on the one hand, and Rohillas, Arabs, Abyssynians and Portuguese of pure or mixed birth and even the so-called Portuguese, or the native converts from Goa were welcomed in his army. They were by no means better soldiers, and were certainly more unscrupulous and less faithful. Yet they obtained from the Peshwa and his feudal chiefs better pay and better treatment than the Marathas proper. Consequently the Maratha army was now gradually, but completely, denationalised. In the Peshwa's personal force the Arabs and other foreigners outnumbered the Marathas; Robert Orme had a very poor opinion of their fighting qualities. In Holkar's army the Pendharis preponderated over the mercenaries; and in Sindhia's forces there were more Purvias than Maratha soldiers. They were bound by no common ideals or common interests and were utterly ruthless in their methods. It was these non-Maratha mercenaries who made the Maratha name dreaded and hated throughout the length and the breadth of the Indian sub-continent. Briefly, then, it may be said that Shivaji had organised a national army; in Rajaram's time the army was feudalised; and it was left to Balaji Baji Rao to denationalise it. This denationalisation with its consequent demoralisation inevitably led to the final overthrow of the Maratha empire. Feudalism in itself was bad, but the employment of foreign mercenaries was, as we shall see, even more disastrous. CHAPTER IV INFANTRY AND CAVALRY KRISHNAJI Anant Sablasad says that Shivaji had 45,000 cavalry and only 10,000 Mawle infantry in his army:8 But the few figures that we have of his expeditionary forces at different dates contradict this estimate. A cavalry trooper was necessarily more expensive. He needed a horse, better equipment and therefore a higher salary. Shivaji's military operations were often confined to hilly regions where horses would be of little or no use. He frequently led his men through unfrequented mountain tracks where the sure-footed Mawle alone could go, and the accuracy of Krishnaji Anant's account is, therefore, more than doubtful.

text: From the few figures available in the contemporary correspondence of the English factors it appears that in Shivaji's time the infantry preponderated over the cavalry. On 12 November 1668, the Carwar factors informed their countrymen at Surat of a report that Shivaji contemplated an expedition to Goa and had with that intent assembled an army of 2,000 horse and 8,000 or 10,000 foot.1 The army that appeared near Hubli in 1670 consisted, according to a report current at Carwar, of 2,000 horse and 4,000 foot.2 In 1675 Shivaji laid siege to the fortress of Phonda and in the besieging force, as we learn from a Carwar letter, dated 14 April, the cavalry was far outnumbered by infantry; their respective strength 2,000 and 7,020.3 On 19 November 1678, the Rajapore factors wrote to their friends at Bombay that the Bijapur generals dared not attack Shivaji who had 15,000 horse and 20,000 foot at Panhala.4 Even in the small force that had joined Sambhaji in his foolish rebellion the cavalry formed the minority, for, when the prodigal son returned to his father's castle at Panhala, he was accompanied, according to an English report, by 300 horse and 1,000 foot.5 The infantry continued to maintain its majority in the Maratha army even after Shivaji's death, for in 1707 Dhanaji Jadhav, as we are told by the Bundela chronicler, had under his command a strong infantry force of 25,000, while his cavalry numbered 5,000 only.6 In the Peshwa period, however, the position was reversed. The Marathas were no longer compelled to defend their hearth and home. Secure in their native territories, they were now in a position to carry war into enemy country, and in these distant expeditions, designed mainly for plunder, a cavalry force was far more useful than infantry. In a Portuguese report, dated June 1787, therefore, we read that the Peshwa could put in the field 80,000 to 100,000 horse, 10,000 foot and 40 to 50 pieces of artillery:7

Composed in the style of the Amara Kosha, this text aims to supply Sanskrit synonyms for Persian words, commonly used during the Peshwa period. During this era, individuals of noble birth were expected to join the army at an early age, a time when others might still be attending school. The text describes the military engagements and the strategic use of forts during the reign of Shivaji, noting that almost all old forts in his country were associated with his name. Some forts were acquired through the use of bribes, others by clever strategy, and the rest through well-planned assaults. Shivaji was not content with just possessing old fortresses; he built new ones, utilizing the hills of Maharashtra as excellent sites for these structures. The entire region was secured with a network of forts, each strategically placed to ensure comprehensive territorial defense.

Shivaji's era did not witness significant advancements in military architecture, primarily because the enemies possessed limited artillery capabilities and lacked advanced mining knowledge. The natural terrain and simple yet massive walls, defended by resolute men, were often sufficient to repel the strongest besieging forces for months. Hunger and bribery were seen as more effective means to conquer a fort than military assault. Each fort was meticulously chosen for its strategic location and natural defenses. Features such as the thorny opuntia cactus made the hill sides even more inaccessible. Every fort was equipped with essential facilities including barracks, granaries, and ample water supplies, ensuring the garrison could withstand prolonged sieges. The strategic placement and robust construction of these forts played a crucial role in resisting Aurangzeb’s invasions, costing the Mughal Emperor significant losses in terms of men, money, and time.

The internal management of the forts under Shivaji was marked by a rigorous system ensuring loyalty and efficiency. Each fort was manned by a carefully selected garrison, with every soldier undergoing personal scrutiny and required to provide a surety for his fidelity. The command of a fort was divided among three officers of equal status but different responsibilities, creating a system of checks and balances. This arrangement prevented any single person from having enough power to betray the fort. The officers included the Havaldar (head of the garrison), the Sabnis (in charge of accounts and muster-rolls), and the Karkhanais (responsible for commissariat duties). Their duties were interlinked, requiring cooperation and mutual oversight, which effectively safeguarded against internal betrayal and ensured the fort's security against all forms of assault.

The Marathas were undoubtedly soldiers, and the Brahmans and Prabhus excelled in accounting and clerical work. However, their professional skills alone don't fully explain Shivaji's caste-based military appointments.  Brahman generals were not scarce, and a Prabhu could likely perform the duties of a Sabnis (record keeper) as well as those of a Karkhannis (clerk). Shivaji mandated that these three officers be of different castes. This minimized collusion and appeased Maharashtra's three main castes by distributing state patronage according to their traditions. Brahmans and Prabhus were not on good terms, and the Marathas generally showed greater loyalty to those of their own caste.  Shivaji thus leveraged the best abilities of the three castes while exploiting their differences to his advantage.

section: Rotation of Officers and Prevention of Corruption
text: Shivaji also addressed the risk of entrenched interests. A Havaldar (fort commander) or a Sabnis, stationed in one place for too long, could build a personal power base. The Bijapur government recognized some officers' hereditary rights (Naikwaris), which often caused problems and delayed new governors' entry into forts. Shivaji countered this by frequently transferring officers between forts, mirroring the rotation of civil governors and ministers.  He recognized no hereditary rights in forts; every officer served at his pleasure, with no claims for relatives upon an officer's death. Despite these precautions, Shivaji couldn't eliminate treason and corruption entirely. During his absence from Raigad, the Sabnis, Keso Narayan, misappropriated funds due to the temporary lack of a Havaldar.  In 1663, a rebellion at Sinhgad fort forced Shivaji to postpone a planned Konkan expedition, highlighting the ongoing challenges of maintaining control and loyalty.

section: Fort Garrisons, Armament, and Defense Strategies
text: Besides the three main officers, each fort had one or more Tat Sarnobats responsible for rampart defense.  Each unit of nine soldiers had a Naik. Garrison size depended on the fort's size, importance, and current threats. Reinforcements, provisions, and stores were sent during times of danger, though typical garrison strength likely didn't exceed five hundred. Soldiers wielded swords, spears, bows and arrows, matchlocks, and muskets. Attackers sometimes used rockets, which were more effective at scaring war elephants than inflicting casualties, and bombs, as seen in the defense of Purandar. Shivaji's artillery was weak, relying on European merchants for guns and ammunition, which were not always top quality. When a fort was threatened, he had to redistribute artillery from other locations. Despite this weakness in firearms, his enemies were often no better equipped. Garrisons often repelled assaults by rolling rocks down on attackers climbing steep hillsides.

section: Fort Capture Methods and the Use of Monitor Lizards
text: Forts could be captured by breaching walls with mines or cannons, or by escalading with ladders.  Shivaji's forces mined Phonda's ramparts in 1675, while Tanaji recaptured Sinhgad by scaling its walls at night.  An ingenious method involved trained monitor lizards (ghorpads).  These lizards, with ropes tied around them, climbed steep surfaces, finding crevices to cling to.  A man could then climb the rope, facilitating infiltration. Vigilance was key to defense.  Countermining opposed enemy mines, but strong hill forts were difficult to mine effectively.  Surprise attacks were the primary danger. Open assaults were typically met with artillery, bombs, rockets, and stones.  Sallies, like Murar Baji Prabhu's at Purandar during Diler Khan's attack, were sometimes necessary. However, forts generally fell due to lengthy sieges and dwindling provisions.

meta.use_case: Siege Warfare Techniques in 17th Century India

text: The siege of Panhala by Sidi Johar prompted Shivaji to improve fort provisioning. In 1671-72, he established a reserve fund of 125,000 Hons (approximately 500,000 rupees) for besieged forts, to be used only when Mughal war erupted and other funds were unavailable.  This fund was raised from various districts and individuals at specific rates. Recognizing the importance of fort maintenance, Shivaji also created a separate fund of 175,000 Hons for repairs. He understood that consistent pay and good treatment were essential to retain skilled workers, noting that irregular wages led to discontent and hindered construction.  This repair fund was allocated to specific forts, with Raigad receiving the largest share.

Shivaji had practically finished building his principal forts by 1671 when a dedicated fund was constituted. This fund, somewhat of a reserve, ensured payment for masons and artisans. Garrison members and officers were not highly paid. A Havaldar earned 125 Hons annually. Nagoji Bhonsle, appointed Havaldar of Fort Utlur in 1677, received 150 Hons, from which he paid two servants 25 Hons each. Krishnaji Survanshi, Sarnobat of Utlur, earned 100 Hons.  Four Tat Sarnobats, sent to manage Kot Utlur's ramparts, received 12 Hons annually (4 ordinary and 8 Kaveripak Hons). Seven Bargirs received 9 Hons each (3 ordinary and 6 Kaveripak). This likely represented standard private pay. Timaji Narayan, a clerk at Valgudanur Fort, received 3 Hons monthly. Besides regular pay, officers received allowances for palanquin, torchbearers, attendants, sunshades, and pages, based on rank and duty importance. Outposts were guarded by Ramoshis, Bhils, and other tribes familiar with the jungle.  Shivaji was the first to employ Ramoshis as fort watchmen, who served loyally.  Their low living standards meant small salaries and perks sufficed. This practice became hereditary. Shivaji's fort administration system survived until the Peshwa period's close but declined after his death.

Shivaji's kingdom, upon his death, had two hundred forts, none held by hereditary nobles. However, his complex system required constant oversight, lacking under Sambhaji.  While Sambhaji retained his father's institutions, he lacked the same foresight and diligence. Things worsened after his death, exemplified by Rairi's betrayal.  Feudalism revived under Rajaram, making chief officers fort custodians.  Purandar was held by the Sachiv, and Parashram Pratinidhi controlled thirty-five forts, including Vishalgad, Pratapgad, Chandan, Wandal, Satara, and Kolhapur. Securing forts for family residences became customary, a practice Balaji Vishwanath followed, obtaining Purandar from Sachiv Shankraji Narayan. Maratha expansion into Malwa and Hindustan saw Peshwa's officers garrisoning newly conquered forts, fostering decentralized control and potential defiance of central authority.

meta.use_case: Impact of Leadership and Political Structures

text: Under the Peshwas, the three old officer positions (Havaldar, Sabnis, Karkhannis) became hereditary (Darakhdars).  Sons or heirs succeeded them, and even during their lifetime, they could appoint agents to perform their duties.  Pay varied based on fort importance, with additional allowances for residing within.  In 1763-64, Bahulz fort's Havaldar and Sarnobat received Rs. 125 annually, while the Sabnis and Fadnis got Rs. 200, and the Subhedar Rs. 250. Chawand and Ahmadnagar Havaldars received Rs. 360 and 300, respectively.  Besides cash, officers received clothing, and some preferred hereditary inam lands. Sinhgad's Sabnis in 1750-51 received Rs. 600 and Rs. 100 worth of clothing, plus two rent-free villages. These officers lost importance under the new system. Fort expenses were covered by revenues from attached villages.  Provincial governors controlled forts; for example, Visaji Keshav managed eighteen Bassein province forts in 1774-75. Anjanvel, a naval station, was jointly controlled by the Havaldar and governor, each holding keys to different gates. This arrangement led to disputes, such as the one in 1794-95 between Governor Bapuji Shinde and Havaldar Babu Rao Salokhe of Dharwar fort.

meta.use_case: Evolution of Administrative and Military Practices

text: Poorly paid Karkhannises sometimes neglected duties, requiring inspectors to examine stores, accounts, rations, and garrison pay. Forced, unpaid labor was used for fort building and repairs, with timber from nearby forests and labor from neighboring villages. Garrison size varied; Satara's was reinforced in 1773-74 due to unrest, and Lohagad's, under Dhondji, ranged from 1,000 to 3,000 men. Private pay improved; under Balaji Baji Rao, it ranged from three to five rupees eight annas monthly, with increments upon transfer. Under Madhav Rao I, it reached seven rupees. Soldiers received ten or eleven months' pay for a year's service, often in arrears. From Shahu's time, payment in rent-free land emerged. By 1774-75, such soldiers served in rotation to manage their lands. Some provided no service and were dismissed. Munro observed a practice in the southern Maratha country: small forts had hereditary garrisons, with commanders and a few followers sent from Poona.  The Peshwas encouraged, sometimes forced, families to live in forts. Shahu had coerced Sheikh Mira's betrayal by arresting his family outside the fort, and the Peshwas feared similar enemy tactics against their officers.

meta.use_case: Evolution of Military Practices and Socioeconomic Factors

section: Military System of the Marathas - Forts and Provisions
text: The government not only permitted the garrison in troubled areas to bring their families within the fort, but also granted them extra allowances and exempted them from some newly imposed taxes. Fort provisions were annually renewed: old grain was sometimes given to the garrison in lieu of pay and sometimes sold, and new grain was bought from the proceeds.  Sometimes the government even stored ordinary spices and tobacco in the forts. During the Peshwa regime, forts were well supplied with artillery, though the artillerymen, mostly foreigners, were of better quality than the ordinary privates. Rockets and rocketers were still employed, but stone guns had not been discarded. Fort guns were cleaned annually (small guns and muskets monthly), but their effectiveness is questionable, given the ease with which the English captured them in 1818.  The army's denationalization also affected the forts, and by Baji Rao II's reign, many fortresses were primarily garrisoned by Arabs and non-Maratha Indians. This situation also prevailed in forts held by feudal subordinates, though these were less efficiently provisioned, especially when the chief was financially strained. While such chiefs could theoretically expect relief from the Peshwa, reinforcements often caused damage to the baron and, consequently, the Peshwa. Despite the natural strength of the country, it offered weak resistance during the final British conquest.

section: Military System of the Marathas - Forts and British Conquest
text: William Henry Tone reported in the late 18th century that the Peshwa ruled a country of great natural strength, with mountains and defiles defended by fortresses used as treasure depots or retreats. He considered the country ideally suited for defensive war, proclaiming it impregnable.  However, Tone's prediction proved false, not because he overstated the land's strength or the forts' value, but because he overlooked the primitive nature of these strongholds – their architecture, management, and weaponry. Since Shivaji's time, there had been no improvements in military architecture, and the revived feudal system had undermined garrison and command efficiency. The artillery, particularly under Baji Rao II, was neglected.  Meanwhile, the English had far surpassed Aurangzib in organization, artillery, and military science.

meta.use_case: Analysis of Military Weaknesses and British Conquest

section: Artillery of the Marathas - Early Acquisition and Dependence on Europeans
text: The Marathas, like other Indians, never excelled in artillery, although they recognized its offensive power.  Babur's victories and the Portuguese dominance in Southern India demonstrated artillery's importance, making it crucial for Indian rulers to acquire this weapon.  While some Indians learned the science, including a Brahman gunner named Rama who engaged in an artillery duel with a Portuguese in 1571,  Indian princes often relied on European adventurers.  Shivaji established an artillery department (Tophkhana) and a gunpowder magazine (Darukhana), possibly emulating the Portuguese. However, he depended on European trading companies for guns and cannons, lacking his own foundry. This wasn't a failing on his part; as a pioneer, he couldn't achieve everything. He likely allowed the French to build a factory at Rajapore and hoped for similar benefits from the English at another port, expecting access to grenades, mortars, and ammunition.

section: Artillery of the Marathas - Shivaji's Attempts to Purchase from the English
text: Shivaji sought artillery from the English, who were hesitant due to potential conflicts with the Delhi government. Despite English reluctance, Shivaji sometimes succeeded. He purchased lead and iron guns from the French in 1673.  English records reveal his persistent requests for engineers, mortars, grenades, and large guns, which he desired to be conveyed privately. He suggested using Portuguese intermediaries to avoid implicating the English. In 1674, he sent an envoy with a letter and gifts, requesting big iron guns and two brass ones. The English lacked spare iron guns, but the brass guns were available. However, they feared provoking the Mughal emperor, who was already suspicious of English supplying Shivaji.  In 1676, the Surat council explicitly forbade Bombay from selling Shivaji the two brass guns, regardless of payment, citing the matter's sensitivity.

meta.use_case: Historical Account of Anglo-Maratha Arms Trade

section: Artillery of the Marathas - Quality of Acquired Guns
text: Shivaji's desperation for artillery led him to acquire even subpar guns. The English and Portuguese, understandably, wouldn't sell their best.  A 1673 Bombay letter details two guns sold to a Frenchman, who then sold them to a merchant at Thana, who subsequently sent them to Shivaji. These were sold by weight and likely of poor quality.  The English factors noted that two guns obtained by Shivaji in 1671 through French and Portuguese agents were "very bad within," though they might last a while with powder and stone shot. A 1672 letter from Surat mentions defects in guns sold that year.
